item.content:encoded:
So, are you going home for lockdown?

In recent years I’ve struggled to answer this question – where is home? Is it where your parents are? Is it the city you were born in or where your books are?

I was born in London. I grew up here, mainly in the South, but lived all over the city in different places with either my mom or dad, neither of which live here anymore. However, when people ask me where I’m from I tend to say Canada. I have spent most of my life visiting my grandparents’ farm every summer in Southey, a tiny town with a population of 400, about forty minutes from the capital of Saskatchewan called Regina, affectionately known as the city that rhymes with fun. The land still seems unfathomably endless to this day. Most people associate ‘home’ with family and friends – I associate it with the smells and sounds of the one unchanged and unmoved place in my life. My mom says it’s where she would go to recharge when returning from being away at university or work and I too see it that way now.

I’ve never spent longer than three years in one place in London and I suspect a lot of people can relate. My memories of these flats and houses are vague and jumbled together and I don’t have any standout moments or specific times that I can recall. But, on my grandparents’ farm, there are two trees, they were planted when I was born and every time I go back there they are, they are as old as me. They’ve weathered the same number of winters as I have, they will always stand there and have always had something that London has lacked; consistency.

I understand that having the option of calling two places home is rare, especially when one allows you to remove yourself from the chaos of the city; enter stillness and calm, and the other is full of culture, diversity and belonging. My slightly skewed definition of ‘home’ does not make it negative, the dual citizenship I hold is something I will always be appreciative of and count myself incredibly fortunate. 

I think the popular idiom ‘home is where the heart is’ makes an exception in some cases; London is where my friends are, the city I know and the streets I’ve grown up on, where I am surrounded by people who love me and who I identify with, but again, that doesn’t satisfy my own definition. Instead, I see London as a base for everything to start and expand from, “Home” for me is yourself. It’s where you are at your best and secretly your worst. It’s that place where you can feel yourself without trying. Where your guard is down and self-defence is your last concern.

So, when people ask me ‘Where are you from’; my knee jerk is Canada, which is ‘technically’ incorrect. But, when I’m driving up the dirt road to the yard and hear the crickets, it feels more like I’m returning than visiting, and seeing London from the sky on the inbound flight always makes me feel out of sorts. I guess home for me is where I hold memories, where I have an anchor, and where I know I can always breathe, home is not temporary for me, it is that one unwavering place.
